3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-profile-idUSKBN1310K2	Fending off foes
column2: Clinton blazes a trail with White House in sight	"

column1: By Will Dunham
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton has one of the strongest resumes of anyone ever to run for U.S. president
column2: with stints as first lady
column3: senator and secretary of state
column4: but she is also a polarizing figure and a Washington insider with decades of political baggage.Should Democrat Clinton
column9: she would become the first woman elected U.S. president
column10: having already been the only first lady to win elected office and the first woman nominated for president by a major U.S. party.Clinton fell short in her first presidential bid in 2008
column11: losing her party's nomination to Barack Obama.Her time on the American political scene has come during an era of intense partisanship and gaping divisions in U.S. society. Americans hold dramatically differing views of Clinton.Clinton's admirers consider her a tough
column12: capable and sometimes inspirational leader who has endured unrelenting efforts by political enemies to chop her down. Her detractors consider her an unscrupulous and power-hungry opportunist.Clinton entered the 2016 race as her party's odds-on favorite
column14: the ultimate insider with decades of political baggage
column15: at a time when voters seemed enamored with outsiders. She staved off an unexpectedly stiff challenge from U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders
column16: who describes himself as a democratic socialist
column17: to claim the Democratic nomination in July.For decades Clinton has battled conservatives and Republican adversaries and weathered controversies including her husband Bill Clinton's infidelity
column18: a failed Republican effort to remove him from office
column19: investigations into past business dealings and her use of a private email server as secretary of state. She famously complained in 1998 during her husband's presidency about a ""vast right-wing conspiracy.""Many Democrats back her for championing women's rights at home and abroad
column20: social justice and access to healthcare
column21: but opinion polls show a majority of U.S. voters do not trust her. [polling.reuters.com/#!poll/TM752Y15_2]Against Trump
column22: she portrayed her candidacy as a bulwark against a unique threat that she said the real estate developer posed to American democracy.As President Obama's secretary of state from 2009 to 2013
column23: she grappled with civil wars in Syria and Libya
column29: and an unsuccessful bid to settle the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.Clinton was already running for president when
column30: during a testy 11-hour congressional hearing in October 2015
column31: she deflected Republican criticism of her handling of a 2012 attack by militants in Benghazi
column32: Libya in which the U.S. ambassador died.That hearing and another in January 2013 while she was still secretary of state focused on allegations of State Department security lapses related to the attack.'WHAT TO MAKE OF ME'

column1: A mistrust of rivals and the media has long prompted Clinton to keep her guard up.""The truth is
column2: through all these years of public service
column3: the 'service' part has always come easier to me than the 'public' part
column4: Clinton said in accepting the 2016 Democratic nomination. ""I get it that some people just don't know what to make of me.""At the same convention
column5: Obama cited her years of experience and said
column6: ""There has never been a man or woman
column8: not Bill - nobody more qualified than Hillary Clinton to serve as president of the United States.""Republicans have accused Clinton of breaking the law while corresponding through a private email server as secretary of state. In July
column9: FBI Director James Comey called Clinton ""extremely careless"" in her handling of classified information by email
column10: but Obama's Justice Department accepted his recommendation not to bring criminal charges.

column1: If I had to do it over again
column2: I would
column3: obviously
column4: do it differently
column5: Clinton said during a Sept. 26 debate with Trump
column6: referring to her use of the private server as a ""mistake"" for which she took responsibility.The controversy flared again on Oct. 28 when Comey told U.S. lawmakers the FBI was investigating a new trove of emails as part of its probe
column7: but said their significance was unclear.Trump seized on the probe into Clinton's email
column9: saying he would seek to put her behind bars if elected and encouraging his supporters to chant ""lock her up.""Clinton portrayed Trump as a racist hate-monger
column10: a sexist and a tax-dodger enamored with Russian President Vladimir Putin and unfit to serve as president and commander in chief.""Such a nasty woman
column11: Trump retorted during their Oct. 19 debate when she suggested he would try to get out of paying the higher taxes she advocates for the wealthy.MIDWESTERN ROOTS

column1: Born in Chicago on Oct. 26
column3: Hillary Rodham Clinton was  the eldest of three children of a small-business owner father she called a ""rock-ribbed
column4: up-by-your-bootstraps
column5: conservative Republican"" and a mother who was a closet Democrat.She said she inherited her father's distinctive laugh - she called it ""a big rolling guffaw"" - and Americans have heard it frequently. She attended public schools
column6: then enrolled in 1965 at all-female Wellesley College in Massachusetts
column7: where she headed the Young Republicans Club.

column1: In a Wellesley commencement address
column2: she seized the spotlight by starting her speech with extemporaneous remarks challenging comments made by the preceding speaker
column3: a U.S. senator.Her political views changed during the 1960s civil rights struggles and Vietnam War escalation. She attended the 1968 Republican convention that nominated Richard Nixon
column4: but soon became a Democrat.At Yale Law School
column5: she met a similarly ambitious fellow student from Arkansas
column7: and they became a couple. She moved to Washington to work for a congressional panel in the impeachment drive against Nixon
column8: who resigned as president in 1974 during the Watergate scandal.She moved to Arkansas to be with Bill
column10: and was hired by a top law firm. He jumped into politics
column13: in 1978. She gave birth to the couple's only child
column16: she was a high-powered lawyer in the capital Little Rock and a Wal-Mart corporate board member.Most Americans were introduced to her during her husband's bid for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination. Bill Clinton said voters would get ""two for the price of one"" if they elected him. She unapologetically said she was not a woman who ""stayed home and baked cookies.""After a woman named Gennifer Flowers accused Bill Clinton during the campaign of a sexual affair
column17: Hillary Clinton appeared on TV with her husband and referred to singer Tammy Wynette's song
column20: some little woman standing by my man like Tammy Wynette
column22: adding that she loved and respected her husband. ""And you know
column23: if that's not enough for people
column26: she added. Conservative critics painted her as a radical feminist and a threat to traditional family values.

column1: WHITE HOUSE CONTROVERSIES
Bill Clinton defeated incumbent Republican President George H.W. Bush in November 1992. As first lady from 1993 to 2001
column2: she was unusually exertive
column3: diving into policy matters unlike many of her predecessors.Critics assailed her failed effort to win congressional passage of healthcare reform
column4: deriding it as ""Hillarycare.""At a 1995 U.N. conference in China on women
column5: she declared that ""human rights are women's rights and women's rights are human rights."" She and her husband faced a long investigation into past business dealings but ultimately no criminal charges were brought. A real estate venture known as Whitewater faced scrutiny
column6: spawning an independent counsel investigation that later encompassed Bill Clinton's sexual relationship with a White House intern named Monica Lewinsky.Deputy White House Counsel Vince Foster
column7: a figure in the Whitewater controversy and a close friend of the Clintons from Arkansas
column8: was found dead of a gunshot in 1993. His death was ruled a suicide. In a 2003 memoir
column9: Hillary Clinton blasted ""conspiracy theorists and investigators trying to prove that Vince was murdered to cover up what he 'knew about Whitewater.'"" In 2000
column10: the independent counsel investigation concluded there was insufficient evidence to show the Clintons had been involved in any criminal behavior related to Whitewater.In December 1998
column11: the Republican-led House of Representatives voted to impeach a president for only the second time in U.S. history
column12: charging Bill Clinton with ""high crimes and misdemeanors"" for allegedly lying under oath and obstructing justice to cover up his relationship with Lewinsky.The Republican-led Senate acquitted Clinton in February 1999. Hillary Clinton called the impeachment an abuse of power by Republicans with a ""Soviet-style show trial"" and condemned what she called ""an attempted congressional coup d'etat.""She also said she ""wanted to wring Bill's neck"" for the affair and upbraided him privately. Ultimately
column14: she decided she still loved him and remained after they went through counseling.""All I know is that no one understands me better and no one can make me laugh the way Bill does
column15: she wrote in her 2003 book ""Living History.""Hillary Clinton soon launched her own bid for elected office. She bought a house in the town of Chappaqua to officially become a New York resident. She won election as a U.S. senator the same month her husband left office in January 2001. She served until 2009.She entered the race for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination as the front-runner
column16: but then-senator Obama won the party's nomination and beat Republican John McCain to become the first black president.In 2016
column17: Obama campaigned vigorously for her against Trump.""What sets Hillary apart is that through it all
column20: and she doesn't stop trying. And she never stops fighting for us
column21: even if we haven't always appreciated it
column22: Obama told a September rally. (Writing and reporting by Will Dunham in Washington; Editing by Howard Goller)"

He said what was happening in Michigan

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-gambling-idUSKBN1320HW	Betting sites see record wagering on U.S. presidential election	"
By Amy Tennery
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK The raucous
column2: passionate and unpredictable 2016 U.S. presidential election is on track to notch another distinction: the most wagered-upon political event ever.With many opinion polls showing a tight race just one day before Tuesday's election
column3: record numbers of bettors are pouring millions into online platforms from Ireland to Iowa in the hope of capturing a financial windfall from a victory by Democrat Hillary Clinton or Republican Donald Trump. UK-based internet betting exchange Betfair said on Sunday its ""Next President"" market was set to become the most traded it had ever seen and expected to surpass even Brexit
column4: the contentious UK referendum to leave the European Union.By Sunday
column5: roughly $130 million had been traded on who will become the next U.S. president
column6: compared with $159 million on the Brexit referendum
column7: Betfair spokeswoman Naomi Totten said. The amount bet so far on the 2016 contest dwarfs the roughly $50 million laid on the 2012 race.""We think it is because (of) how raw the Brexit (vote) is in people's minds - they're not convinced yet that it's a done deal
column8: Totten said.Most polls leading into Britain's June 23 referendum predicted Britons would choose to remain in the EU. Instead
column9: they voted to leave by a 52 percent to 48 percent margin.Betfair's ""Next President"" market was by far the largest of more than 70 markets on the site related to the U.S. election. As of Friday
column10: some $140 million has been put into play on markets ranging from who will win the popular vote to how many states each party will carry.On Ireland's Paddy Power
column11: which merged with Betfair earlier this year
column12: the U.S. presidential election ""is definitely on course to be the biggest political event
column13: said spokesman Feilim Mac An Iomaire. The site has had about $4.38 million bet on the race so far.For Paddy Power
column14: sporting events remain the site's ""bread and butter
column15: with politics more of a ""niche market
column17: he expects the 2016 race to be among the top 10-most-traded events on the site.Even people with no knowledge of politics know who Trump is
column19: explaining the runaway popularity of the U.S. election in betting markets. ""Trump is such a huge celebrity.""

column1: Ladbrokes
column2: a UK-based gambling company
column3: said about 5 million pounds
column4: or a little over $6 million
column5: had been bet on the 2016 presidential election since its markets on the race opened four years ago. A Ladbrokes spokesman said that amount was ""at least double"" the amount wagered on the 2012 election.The three sites all reported an 83 percent probability of a Clinton victory on Tuesday. Her probability shot up a few percentage points on Sunday after the FBI stood by its earlier recommendation that no criminal charges were warranted against Clinton in her use of a private email server. BACK IN THE USA

column1: The vast majority of big-dollar political betting occurs outside America. Wagering on elections in the United States is limited by law to relatively small trading platforms connected to universities
column2: which use data from the markets for academic research.

column1: Still
column2: the sites are abuzz with activity as the election nears
column3: albeit in small amounts. On PredictIt
column4: launched in 2014 and jointly run by Victoria University in Wellington
column7: D.C.-based political consulting firm Aristotle International Inc
column8: the five most-active markets all related to the presidential election.PredictIt is not legally permitted to disclose the amount of money traded
column9: but its top three markets have all reached the maximum number of participants.Trading on the older Iowa Electronic Markets
column10: launched by the University of Iowa in 1988
column12: although a spokeswoman said she could not say if 2016 was seeing substantially more volume than in 2012
column13: when President Barack Obama won re-election against Republican Mitt Romney.The latest Reuters/Ipsos poll showed Clinton with a 5 percentage point lead over Trump in the national survey - 44 percent to 39 percent - while races in the swing states of Florida
column14: North Carolina had shifted from Clinton's control to being too close to call.

column1: The PredictIt market gave Clinton an 81 percent probability of winning the White House. IEM's ""Winner Takes All"" market showed her with a 71 percent chance .'SHE WILL WIN IN A LANDSLIDE'

Betfair said on Friday that Trump was emerging as the clear favorite among one group of players in particular - Brexit backers. Two-thirds of its customers who had supported a Brexit outcome were also backing Trump on Betfair.Paul Krishnamurty
column2: a professional gambler for 15 years who works as an analyst at Betfair and a columnist at Politico
column3: is not one of them. He told Reuters he stood to lose $28
column4: 000 if Trump wins on Tuesday.Krishnamurty
column5: who said he had earned roughly half a million dollars during his betting career
column6: has laid money on several election-related markets this year. He took a winning position on Trump's selection of Indiana Governor Mike Pence as his running mate and bet against Jeb Bush during the Republican nominating contests. He said he believed Clinton would likely to win both North Carolina and Florida and that a Trump victory was unlikely.""I personally believe she will win in a landslide
column7: Krishnamurty said. (Reporting by Amy Tennery; Editing by Dan Burns and and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKBN1310WY	FBI clears Clinton in email review two days before election	"
By Alana Wise and Mark Hosenball
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The FBI said on Sunday it stood by its earlier finding that no criminal charges were warranted against Democrat Hillary Clinton for using a private email server for government work
column2: lifting a cloud over her presidential campaign two days before the U.S. election.FBI Director James Comey made the announcement in a letter to Congress
column3: saying the agency had worked ""around the clock"" to complete its review of newly discovered emails and found no reason to change its July finding.""During that process
column4: we reviewed all of the communications that were to or from Hillary Clinton while she was secretary of state
column6: we have not changed our conclusions that we expressed in July.""A law enforcement source told Reuters the decision closed the FBI probe of Clinton's email practices. Comey informed Congress of the newly discovered emails more than a week ago
column7: throwing the race for the White House into turmoil and helping to erode Clinton's lead over Republican candidate Donald Trump in the final stretch before Tuesday's vote.""We're glad this issue is resolved but for the record
column8: this could easily have been learned before 1st letter was sent
column9: Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon wrote on Twitter.At a rally in Michigan
column10: Trump questioned the thoroughness of the FBI review and said he was confident the issue would not go away.""The investigation will go on
column11: the rank-and-file special agents won't let her get away with her terrible crimes
column12: he told supporters in Sterling Heights

column1: Clinton did not mention the FBI email decision during campaign appearances in Ohio and New Hampshire.U.S. stock index futures rose more than 1 percent after the FBI announcement
column2: suggesting Wall Street was poised to end its longest skid in more than three decades. The U.S. dollar also jumped in Asian trading against the yen
column3: euro and Swiss franc.U.S. Treasury futures dropped and Tokyo's Nikkei share average opened up 1.31 percent. Global financial markets slipped last week as opinion polls showed the presidential race tightening.DEMOCRATS NOT LETTING COMEY OFF HOOK

column1: The latest emails were discovered as part of a separate probe of former Democratic U.S. Representative Anthony Weiner
column2: the estranged husband of Clinton aide Huma Abedin. Weiner is the target of an FBI investigation into illicit text messages he allegedly sent to a 15-year-old girl in North Carolina.Federal investigators got a warrant to examine the emails to see if they were related to the probe into Clinton's private server. Democrats reacted angrily to Comey's intrusion into the race and demanded quick action in examining the emails.""I am very grateful to the professionals at the FBI for doing an extraordinary amount of high-quality work in a short period of time
column3: Comey said on Sunday.But Democrats did not let Comey and the FBI off the hook. U.S. Senator Dianne Feinstein of California said Sunday's announcement made Comey's earlier letter ""even more troubling"" and called for the Justice Department to review its procedures to prevent similar actions to influence future elections.

column1: By confirming that the new emails were meaningless
column2: today's letter underscores the irresponsibility of Director Comey's original letter
column3: Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid said.Republicans kept up their criticism of Clinton despite Comey's announcement.""She simply believes she's above the law and always plays by her own rules
column4: House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan said in a statement
column5: arguing that Clinton's use of a private email server ""compromised our national security.""Republican National Committee Chairman Reince Preibus said that while the probe had not led to criminal charges
column6: it produced evidence that Clinton broke the law and ""repeatedly lied to the American people about her reckless conduct.""News of the renewed probe had appeared to fuel a recent slide in Clinton's poll numbers. The latest Reuters/Ipsos poll showed Clinton with a 5 percentage point lead over the New York businessman nationally - 44 percent to 39 percent support - while races in the swing states of Florida and North Carolina shifted from favoring Clinton to being too close to call.The Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project estimates that Clinton has a 90 percent chance of winning the election. (Additional reporting by Richard Cowan; Writing by John Whitesides; Editing by Paul Simao and Peter Cooney)"
